title: Is my spouse liability for a monetary judgement against me?
question: I have been issued a Summons for Unlawful Detainer - eviction of a commercial property for not paying the last 5 months of rent. Total amount owed is $88,000. If there is a judgement against me and they put a lien on the property that i share with my wife (we both purchase property after marriage), will the lien amount only go against my portion of the property (and therefore 50%) or is my wife liable for my part of the debt?
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Inheritance and divorce,Community property in divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Inheritance rights,Trusts,Living trust,Filing a lawsuit
answers:
Generally speaking, the "community estate" - meaning the assets owned by you and your wife - is liable for debts incurred before or during the marriage. There may be a way to negotiate down the amount of rent due and avoid a judgment from being levied against you. As to the trust, it depends on the way the trust is structured and whether you are currently receiving any funds from the trust.
